awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research/RUI: Dynamic Control and Separation of Microparticles in Fluids using Optical Whispering Gallery Mode Resonant Forces
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to create a new method for selective motion control of micrometer-sized particles suspended in liquids. The method is based on an optical counterpart to "whispering gallery" resonance observed in certain structures, in which a sound made at one point may be heard clearly in certain other special spots, even though it may be inaudible everywhere else. In this project, a suspended spherical particle plays the role of the whispering gallery, with the resonance determined by its diameter and optical properties relative to the surrounding liquid. Laser light with wavelength matched to the whispering gallery resonance will apply significant optical forces to the particle, while particles of even slightly different diameters will feel no effect. This allows extremely selective particle manipulation and separation based on size and optical characteristics, enabling compact and robust micro-opto-fluidic devices for use in industry, healthcare, and environmental applications. The project will engage students from Gordon College, an undergraduate institution, in state-of-the-art collaborative research and advance the growth of an undergraduate-focused research infrastructure. Gordon College undergraduates will develop hands-on expertise in optics, microfabrication, microfluidics, and control. The project will also engage graduate students from Boston University, a major research university, who will obtain valuable teaching and research mentoring skills.

This project will investigate a method of separation using evanescent optical fields around an optical waveguide to exert forces on microparticles that are being carried in a flow field. These microparticles possess whispering gallery mode resonances that are known to be strongly dependent on the shape and size of the particles, ensuring an unprecedented selectivity of particles with narrowly defined geometric characteristics. Careful control of the forces and flow velocities allows for the design of particle trajectories, directing the selected ones into reservoirs to accomplish separation. To increase throughput, a networked control system model will be leveraged and communication and control policies designed that leverage the single actuation channel to simultaneously steer particles of different specific sizes. The project's approach has several desirable aspects: it has exquisite and tunable selectivity; it is applicable to solid particles as well as suspended liquid droplets; and it can be used in a compact and robust micro-opto-fluidic device. This work will advance fundamental science and engineering in several directions. It will provide detailed parametric study of the light propelling forces due to whispering gallery mode resonances and help to develop a fundamental understanding of the phenomenon.  The particle separation application allows for the development of technology useful across various fields while also providing a setting to develop the field of networked control theory. Because a single actuator is employed to control the movement of multiple particles, this work requires a novel application of networked control theory and a new domain for exploring and resolving challenges in this field. The research will also push the boundaries in experimental fluid dynamics and optical science leading to the fabrication and test of a micro-opto-fluidic device.

por.por_cntn:
The term ?whispering gallery? is coming from architectural acoustics: buildings with round rotundas or domes are famous for the phenomenon, when a sound wave can travel around the circle for multiple times. If the wave after the round trip returns to the source of sound in phase with the source, i.e., if the circumference fits an integer number of waves, a Whispering Gallery Mode (WGM) resonance occurs. At resonance, acoustic energy literally gets trapped by the structure, and the wave may be amplified dramatically. A very similar phenomenon exists in optics, when transparent particles of spherical, cylindrical, elliptical, or toroidal shape can trap light of WGM resonant wavelengths. A remarkable feature of this phenomenon is that the WGM resonances are very sharp and narrow, and their positions are strictly determined by particle materials and dimensions. Moreover, as we demonstrated, under the resonance condition the trapped light causes giant amplification of the light propelling forces, such that even relatively big particles, of the order of 10-20 micron, may be forced to move.   

In this project we develop capabilities of the WGM resonance phenomenon to sort the suspended in water particles by their sizes. In the prototype device, the WGM resonances are excited by the evanescent light from the tapered optical fiber fed by the radiation of 25-50 mW laser. When a WGM particle approaches the taper, if the WGM resonance matches the wavelength of the laser, the particle gets trapped at the taper and propelled along it by the distance that several times exceeds the size of a particle. This distance is sufficient to transport the particle to a dedicated compartment where it can be stored for future usage.  If the WGM resonance of the particle does not match the wavelength of light, such particle passes by the fiber without being trapped and transported. Thus, the dedicated compartment will have only the particles whose resonance matches the wavelength of laser light.

Whereas we established the principle and built several versions of prototype sorting device, developing a robust working device requires further work. The most significant challenge is designing microfluidic channels with laminar flow of the particles throughout the whole device, including the neighborhood of the tapered fiber. Otherwise, the turbulences not only disrupt the trapping and transporting of the particles with light, but also their cause chaotic motion of particles and clog in the microfluidic channels.

Results of this work are useful to advance optics, photonics, microfluidics, and physics of non-linear phenomena. This work is also beneficial for biomedical and drug production.

It is particularly important that most of the work on this project was done by undergraduate students, who, thus, obtained their first experience of true scientific research and creative work. Over the course of five years, this project employed seven undergraduate students, two of these students graduated with Departmental Honors; four students continued their study towards engineering degrees. It is difficult to overestimate the value of this award for Gordon College, which is a small liberal arts college that maintains a rigorous science and engineering curriculum. Equipment acquired for this project allowed us to improve teaching of courses in Optics, Modern Physics, Electronics, Materials Science, and Laboratory Techniques. This project has been an important factor in attracting new talented students and faculty members. Support of this project has enabled representatives of under-represented minorities, black and female to receive training in science and technology. This grant gave Gordon College an opportunity to provide the students with true research experience, and excite them about research career, which otherwise would not be possible.
